quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Methods[/h1]

In the previous lessons we have seen some examples of methods, such as the [b]reverse [/b]method for arrays.
A [b]method [/b]is a set of statements that perform a specific task. 
You can define your own methods to perform your desired tasks.
The [b]def [/b]keyword is used to define a method. [code format="rb" ][b]def[/b] say
  puts "Hi"
end[/code]
The above code defines a method called "say" that performs a simple output operation, printing "Hi".
[note]The method name should start with a [b]lowercase [/b]letter, so it will not be confused with constants.[/note]

quizzes.question: Rearrange the code to define a method that outputs "Demo" and then calls the method.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Calling Methods[/h1]

Now that we have defined our method, we can call it by including its name in a line of code: [code format="rb" codeId="1040"]def say
  puts "Hi"
end

[b]say[/b]
# outputs "Hi"[/code]
You can call methods as many times as you need: [code format="rb" codeId="1041"]say
say
say[/code]
[note]Methods should be defined before calling them, otherwise Ruby will raise an error.
You can also call methods inside other methods.[/note]
